div.head: Way to prepare aspalt spat
div.ab: It is found in earth in Germany, the color of cooked plaster, made of long filaments, very soft to handle. And because it is mixed with earth and filth, one pestles it roughly &one makes little balls, having, for this purpose, soaked it in sal ammoniac water of such a composition that you were told above. One places these balls to reheat in the fire of the furnace of the potters, then one soaks it again in the same water. The earth and the coarseness and go to the bottom, and the pure aspalt, which is light & soft and handleable as wet flour, adheres with the water and goes to the surface, clouding the water, empty that cloudy part in a separate receptacle. Having sat, one, one empties the water by tilting, or by taking it away with a sponge, and the pureaspalt remains at the bottom. Dry it & employ it in frame, having been moistened with sal ammoniac water. And try it in the frame, in which it shrinks when reheated or dried, that is to say that one needs to reheat it again on a good fire and redden it. Thus, for medals and flat things, you should use this one, because it is the most perfect of all for gold, silver, copper, lead, latten, & tin, for it withstands the fire & reddens whenever need be, without corrupting. The more it is used, the b better it is, & it does not spoil. At the beginning it is white, & being used it becomes grey. However make sure to put aside the one that served for casting lead & tin & latten, for gold would sour in it, & would not come out of it well. And to do this better, you could put it aside to be used for each metal.

left-top
It endures ten or twelve castings without corrupting, it withstands the fire & reddens, it is suitable for all metals. It is so tenacious that should the frame be straked, it holds.

left-middle
The spat almost does not set, even though it is reheated & is a kind of plaster. Raw, it breaks easily with the fingers.

div.head: Excellent secret for molding hollow and very delicately in fine gold
div.ab: Cast with your aforementioned sand your animal and lizard or other thing with argent de billon & it will come out very neat. E But take heed to mold it hollow, or at least leave a small hole, in its mouth or in another place. Next, gild it with fine gold, as uniform as it will be possible for you, three or four or five times, & until your gold has the thickness of a piece of paper or something similar, & all the scales will always show equally. Next, put it in good aquafortis, which, by this hole, will corrode the billon & the gold will remain hollow & light & wonderful.
